message: I awake to a suffocating feeling of nostalgia.
I get out of bed, rubbing my eyes.
That dream was a memory from when we were kids, before Koujaku left Midorijima.

I met him one day after he moved into our neighborhood.

He lived alone with his mother, just like I did with Granny, so we played at each other's houses a lot.
Granny was often away for work. I told myself it was no big deal, but sometimes, I'd get these panic attacks.
Now that I think about it, I must have been repressing my loneliness, telling myself that Granny was busy and I shouldn't be a bother.
She's the only family I have. It's no wonder I felt insecure.
When my anxiety got the better of me, I'd run out of the house crying.
And Koujaku... he would be the one to find me.
He'd always find me... no matter where I went.
As a kid, I wasn't much good at talking to people. I mostly kept quiet, head bowed.
But Koujaku was always patient. He'd wait as long as it took for me to open up, and he'd always keep me company until Granny came home.
It was so reassuring, having him around. I came to think of him as kind of a superhero. Not that I'd ever admit that now.
He always tried to understand me.
He was always there, waiting just a few steps ahead, never too far to catch.
Something changed when we grew up.
I mean, of course it would, right? It's not like we could be kids forever.

That dream made me realize something: that unconditional trust is a luxury for children.

As adults, we learn to question people's motives, to assume things based on how we think people should be.
Bit by bit, those assumptions diverge from the truth. And that's why it's like this between us now.
But that dream showed me something else, too. It showed me the one thing that hasn't changed.
Koujaku is hiding something from me. There's no question about that.
But when he said that he wanted to protect me―that wasn't a lie.
The expression on his face when he said that... was the same as it was all those years ago.
I'll just have to trust that, if nothing else.
I want to trust him, just like he did back then, believing that I would open up.

name: 蒼葉
message: "...Alright."
No time to be sitting here, pondering my dreams. I get out of bed and start Ren up.

name: 蓮
message: "Good morning, Aoba."

name: 蒼葉
message: "Morning... Hm?"
My jacket is laid out on top of my bed. When I pick it up, I notice it smells of detergent.
Koujaku must have washed it together with his kimono.
I pick up my jacket and leave the room. I need to talk to Koujaku.
Standing in front of his door, I gather my courage.
Just act normal. Like nothing's changed.
I take a deep breath and knock.
No response. I wait a little longer, but nothing. It doesn't sound like there's anyone inside.
Is he...
I throw the door open.
...The room is empty.
He went out on his own? Again?
Pain flares in my chest. I struggle to ignore it.
I've decided to trust him, but it's still a shock to know that he left me behind.
I hate myself so much for feeling this way.
But at the same time, I know that doubting him is pointless. He must have a reason for acting this way.
I don't know what that reason is... but there's a good chance he's caught up in something serious.
He's never been the type to ignore something once it's landed on his shoulders.
I close the door slowly.
...I trust Koujaku.
I've already made my decision. I'm going to trust him, no matter what.

name: 蒼葉
message: "Ren. Let's go find him."

name: 蓮
message: "Understood."
Going after Toue is important, but right now, I want to make Koujaku my priority. He's important to me too.
And something tells me that leaving him alone is a recipe for disaster.
I send Koujaku a message, just in case, then dash down the stairs and out the front door.
